title: What are the benefits and drawbacks of using FreeBSD daily? - Quora

response.answer_text: superior security in general (much over Linux and Windows) and high performance and reliability of server-side services, far superior to Linux in most benchmark teststotally open source (except of some proprietary drivers, i.e. Nvidia)entire system and programs from ports are compillable and highly configurablemany windows managers available (I recommend KDE, but for less powerful machines, some recommend Xfce, etc.)wide HW compatibility - highly comparable with Linux, sometimes even betteressential SW available - Mozilla Firefox, Opera, Iridium, Calligra Office, OpenOffice, LibreOffice, VirtualBox, KDevelop, Qt Creator, Kdenlive video editor, games - i.e. 0ad, flight simulators, etc. and more than 30.000 ports to downloadbinary compatibility with Linux - you can run almost every Linux program without emulationsuitable for web server, mail, firewall, proxy, workstation - I think a good choice for pre-production, testing and development, as I doZ-file system native support is a big advantage - suitable for data centerswell documented, so everybody can learn and configureIntel dedicated staff to ensure FreeBSD compatibility (it seems that Intel might work best here)completely usable in console-only modeDrawbacks: sometimes, it’s difficult to configure something and you should verify HW and open source driver availability and/or its performance, if you buy a machine for FreeBSDIMHO: high dependency on internet connection if you install or update system with GUI (mentioned KDE, for example) or other bigger programsif you prefer simple and easy instalation with GUI by default, official documentation recommends TrueOS (based on FreeBSD), however, I didn’t test itactually, behind Linux in supercomputers support (SMP)I currently miss a native HTML WYSIWYG/SRC editorDRM supportUpdated due to comments of readers.
